flowRoot.flowPara: The impact of human fire starts and land use on burnt area
Global fire models typially described burnt area as
a consequence of fuel load, moisture, natural & anthropagenic ignition and land use suppression (Rabin et al. 2017). A lack of information on
temporal & spatial distribution of these controls has meant their distribution is largely untested. Here,
we map the limitation and sensitivity of burnt area
to Fuel, Moisture, Ignitions and Suppression controls by opQtimizing a simple fire limitation
model, with meteorological and remote sensed inputs, against monthly gridded burnt area.
model calculates burnt area (BA) as a product of the "maximum fire" (F(x)) for each control:
Each limitation is represented by a logistic
function, left, where x is the control. For fuel,
X is represented by one variable. For other controls, X is a linear aggregation of variables
MODIS fractional vegetation cover (Townshend et al. 2001) is used to assess the impact of fuel dicontinuity on burnt aread Proxies for fuel load (i.e NPP) can also be assessed seperatly.
a sub annual cycle. Small maps show values
during the month of the year with maximum fire

moisture is represented by soil moisture simulated from a simple water balance model (SLASH: Davis et al. 2017), and dead fuel moisture by the "equilbrium moisture content", loosly related to humidity (Kelley et al.
Lightning sources are from rescaled LIS (Kelley et al. 2014) &
Population Density is used for both
ignitions and suppression. Suppression also includes agricultural land
parameters (x0, k and ci) are optimized against monthly 0.5 degree burnt area (GFED4s: Giglio et al.
2013) using a Baysian Optimization Framework (see web
address in footer for more info)
Shaded regions on line plots show average
annual range of limitation imposed by each control for four points: Desert (fuel limited); Rainforest (moisture);
land used). Dots are annual average limitation,
whereas the sensitivity to change in a control
can be calculated from the gradient (coloured lines)
